cells.data:
Q: If $B$ is an $m \times n$ matrix and $S$ is an invertible $m \times m$ matrix, show that $B$ and $A = S \cdot B$ have the same rank.

A: Consider first the rank of $B$: being the dimension of the column space, we know $rank(B) \in [0,n]$
Consider second the properties of $S$. $S$ is square and invertible, so we know that it's columns are linearly independent. Further, we then know that the span of the column space of $S$ is "full"; that is, $rank(S) = m$ and $null(S) = \{0\}$. Finally, we know that we can row-reduce $S$ to be $I_m$, so $S \sim I_m$. This is easy to show, since $S$'s linearly independent columns must form a basis for $\mathbb{R}^m$, and the easiest such basis $\matrixstart e_1 \dots e_m \matrixend$ is equivalent.

Now, $A = S \cdot B \sim I_m \cdot B = B$, so $A \sim B$ and therefore they have the same rank (the column space and row space are equivalent). $\square$

I have neither given nor recieved any aid on this assignment: David Ben Knoble.
I verify that this is my own intellectual work: David Ben Knoble.
